Introduction

Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) prevent presynaptic reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine in the synaptic cleft.  SNRIs are used to treat depression and anxiety, as well as pain disorders.  They have similar safety profiles to selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), but many SNRIs can be associated with elevations in blood pressure.

Mechanism of action



In the brainstem, serotonergic (serotonin-releasing) neurons are found primarily in the raphe nuclei, located in the midbrain, pons, and medulla.  Noradrenergic (norepinephrine-releasing) neurons are found in the locus coeruleus, located in the dorsal pons.  Axons from these cell bodies project widely throughout the CNS to synapse on structures such as the cerebral cortex, thalamus, hypothalamus, cerebellum, hippocampus, and spinal cord.



Both serotonin and norepinephrine are implicated in neuronal pathways affecting mood and anxiety.  In the synapse, SNRIs inhibit both serotonin and norepinephrine transporter proteins and block the presynaptic reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine, increasing their availability in the synaptic cleft.  This action strengthens postsynaptic serotonin and norepinephrine receptor activity, leading to downstream therapeutic effects on mood and anxiety.



By modulating both serotonergic and noradrenergic pathways, SNRIs can affect a wider range of depression and anxiety symptoms with greater magnitude compared to SSRIs, which target only serotonin.  SNRIs also increase norepinephrine in the descending pain pathways, diminishing the central perception of pain.

Indications



SNRIs are used to treat the following psychiatric conditions:



  • Major depressive disorder (MDD)
  • Generalized anxiety disorder
  • Social anxiety disorder
  • Panic disorder


SSRIs and SNRIs are first-line options for MDD due to their efficacy and tolerability.  SNRIs are often preferred as an initial treatment when targeting comorbid depression and pain conditions.  In addition, duloxetine is an SNRI that can be used to treat fibromyalgia, diabetic neuropathy, and chronic musculoskeletal pain.

SNRI options



Effectiveness is similar among SNRIs, although differences exist in relative affinities for the serotonin and norepinephrine transporter.



  • Venlafaxine:  primarily serotonergic at lower doses
  • Desvenlafaxine:  metabolite of venlafaxine with increased norepinephrine potency
  • Duloxetine:  used to treat chronic pain syndromes (eg, fibromyalgia, diabetic neuropathy, chronic musculoskeletal pain)
  • Levomilnacipran:  more potent norepinephrine reuptake inhibition

Drug-drug interactions



Duloxetine significantly inhibits CYP2D6, which can decrease metabolism of prodrug to active metabolite (eg, conversion of opioid precursors such as codeine to morphine).  Venlafaxine, desvenlafaxine, and levomilnacipran do not have significant cytochrome P450 enzyme effects.

Adverse effects and management

Increased blood pressure



Compared to SSRIs, the primary difference in the safety profile of SNRIs is increased blood pressure due to increased noradrenergic drive.  In particular, venlafaxine may increase blood pressure in a dose-dependent manner.  Blood pressure should be measured before starting an SNRI and should also be regularly monitored throughout treatment.  If elevated blood pressure is sustained, consider reducing the dose, switching to an alternative antidepressant, or starting antihypertensive treatment.  Duloxetine has minimal effects on blood pressure.



Otherwise, SNRIs have similar safety profiles as SSRIs.

Gastrointestinal effects



Gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms are common with initiation or dose increases of SNRIs but are usually transient and resolve after a few weeks.  Typical symptoms include nausea (most common), decreased appetite, vomiting, and diarrhea.



Management includes reassurance that these symptoms are generally self-limited and educating patients to take SNRIs with a meal, which can help alleviate GI distress.  If symptoms are severely distressing or persistent, consider switching to a different antidepressant.

Sexual dysfunction



Sexual dysfunction is common with any SNRI (

).  Symptoms include decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, delayed orgasm, and anorgasmia.  These effects are a common cause of medication nonadherence.



Sexual dysfunction can occur within 1-2 weeks of initiation.  It may resolve over time (eg, within 2-8 weeks) but can often persist with continued SNRI use.  Symptoms usually resolve a few weeks after discontinuing the SNRI.



Management of persistent sexual dysfunction depends on the patient's response to the SNRI as well as severity of the sexual dysfunction:



  • If the patient has a good response to the SNRI (eg, â‰¥50% depressive symptom reduction) with mild-to-moderate sexual dysfunction, add an adjunctive agent with phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors (eg, sildenafil) or bupropion.
  • If the patient has partial or no response to the SNRI or sexual dysfunction is severe despite good response, switch to an atypical antidepressant, such as bupropion or mirtazapine.

Increased risk of suicidal thoughts and behaviors



All antidepressants, including SNRIs, have an FDA black box warning for increased risk for suicidal thinking and behavior in children, adolescents, and young adults age <25.  This warning is based on an analysis of placebo-controlled trials that reflected a 4% risk of suicidality in those taking antidepressants versus 2% in those not taking antidepressants.  No deaths by suicide were attributed to antidepressant use.  The benefit of antidepressant treatment in reducing symptoms of depression (a primary factor in reducing suicide risk) typically outweighs this risk.



In patients age <25, SNRIs remain an important treatment option.  Carefully monitor and educate patients and their families to watch for increased suicidality when an antidepressant is initiated or titrated.

Hyponatremia



Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) (

) is a rare adverse effect of SNRIs but should be considered in patients with the following risk factors: advanced age (>65), female sex, concomitant use of thiazide diuretics, and a baseline plasma sodium <138 mEq/L.  Patients may be asymptomatic, mildly symptomatic (eg, nausea, lethargy) or, in severe cases, present with delirium, profound confusion, seizures, or coma.



Laboratory findings include low sodium levels, low serum osmolality (275 mOsm/kg), high urine osmolality (>100 mOsm/kg), and an elevated urine sodium concentration (>40 mEq/L).



Management includes discontinuing the SNRI and fluid restriction.  In severe cases, hypertonic saline is used.



Once medically stabilized, a trial of a non-SNRI antidepressant medication or an alternate SNRI can be attempted with close monitoring for hyponatremia recurrence.

Overdose



Overdose of venlafaxine can result in tachycardia, hypotension, cardiac conduction abnormalities (eg, QT prolongation), respiratory depression, and seizures.  Isolated overdoses of other SNRIs are generally much safer compared to those of other antidepressants, such as tricyclic antidepressants (TCAs).  Patients are frequently asymptomatic or have mild CNS depression.



Management includes laboratory evaluation for co-ingestants (eg, acetaminophen, salicylates, ethanol), especially with more severe symptoms, including altered mental status (eg, not following commands, withdrawing to painful stimuli) or abnormal physical examination findings.  An ECG should be performed to assess QT prolongation.  Glucose and serum bicarbonate should be collected to rule out hypoglycemia and metabolic acidosis.

Serotonin syndrome



SNRIs may result in excessive serotonergic activity that can cause serotonin syndrome (

figure 1
).  Symptoms typically include fever, mental status changes, autonomic instability, hyperreflexia, and clonus.  This syndrome rarely occurs at therapeutic doses but may occur with concurrent use of other serotonergic drugs (eg, TCAs, monoamine oxidase inhibitors [MAOIs], dextromethorphan, tramadol, amphetamines, ecstasy).  Therefore, caution should be exercised when prescribing an SNRI along with other serotonergic agents.  SNRIs are contraindicated within 14 days of MAOI use due to irreversible binding of MAOIs to monoamine oxidase, which could result in excess serotonin activity.



Treatment for serotonin syndrome is primarily supportive (eg, intravenous fluids, blood pressure stabilization), benzodiazepines for agitation, and antihypertensives if necessary.  If symptoms are unresponsive to supportive care, cyproheptadine (serotonin antagonist) may be considered.



A more detailed review of this topic is available in a separate, dedicated article.

Discontinuation syndrome



Abrupt discontinuation or rapid tapering of SNRIs may lead to uncomfortable symptoms, although usually not severe or persistent.  Common symptoms include headache, nausea, fatigue, dizziness, and mood changes (eg, dysphoria, anxiety, irritability).  Flu-like symptoms (eg, myalgias, chills, diaphoresis), insomnia, and neurosensory disturbances (eg, paresthesia, "electric shock" sensations, vivid dreams) may also occur.



All SNRIs have relatively short half-lives of <24 hours.  Symptom onset after discontinuation can be as little as 1 day following a missed dose.  Discontinuation symptoms can be more severe after abrupt discontinuation at higher doses and/or longer treatment duration (eg, on maximum dose of an SNRI for years).



Management includes restarting the antidepressant at the existing dose, which should result in rapid improvement of symptoms.  If discontinuation is intended, reattempt the taper at a slower rate (generally over the course of 2-4 weeks) or switch to fluoxetine, given its longer half-life, and then taper.

Summary



Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRIs) inhibit both serotonin and norepinephrine transporter pumps and increase serotonin and norepinephrine concentrations in the synaptic cleft.  SNRIs are used to treat depression and anxiety and some, such as duloxetine, can also be used to treat certain pain syndromes.  Efficacy and safety profiles of SNRIs are similar to selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs), although many SNRIs are associated with dose-dependent elevations in blood pressure.  Given their short half-lives (<24 hours), discontinuation symptoms are likely if SNRIs are abruptly discontinued.
